prompt: The Brits are threatening a 'digital border' again post-Brexit. A startup in Dundalk proposes a smart camera system that scans license plates and faces to keep the border 'frictionless' for trade but tracks every movement between North and South. Do we prioritize the free flow of goods if it means building the most sophisticated surveillance infrastructure in Europe right on the line we spent decades trying to erase?

The PSNI want to link their facial recognition database with An Garda Síochána to catch dissidents operating cross-border. It sounds grand for security, but given the history of collusion and files going missing in this country, can we trust an algorithm trained on British intelligence data to fairly identify a lad in South Armagh, or is this just digital internment?

Farmers along the border are being offered 'agri-tech' grants for drones to monitor livestock, but the data feeds directly into customs compliance servers in London and Dublin. It stops diesel smuggling and cattle laundering, sure, but it essentially turns every sheep farmer in Fermanagh into a reluctant border guard. Do we accept the grant or keep the gates locked?

A Peace Process monitoring app asks residents near interface areas in Belfast to log 'sectarian incidents' in real-time to deploy youth workers. It's meant to de-escalate, but the locals know that data is one hack away from being a loyalist or republican targeting list. Do we digitize the peace walls or is silence safer?

Mobile roaming data shows thousands of people technically 'working' in the South while living in the North, dodging tax residency rules. Revenue wants to use cell tower triangulation to automate tax audits. It's technically fraud, but it's also the only way families in border counties are surviving the cost of living crisis. Do we enforce the law or look the other way?

Biometric checks are being piloted for the Dublin-Belfast Enterprise train. They say it's for 'efficiency' and 'immigration control', but for anyone who remembers being pulled off that train by soldiers in the 80s, a face scan feels a lot like a checkpoint. Is a seamless journey worth the psychological trigger of a hard border in digital clothing?

An AI system aims to predict 'flashpoints' during marching season using social media sentiment analysis and historical riot data. It suggests preemptive road closures. It might save cars from being burnt, but it effectively creates a 'pre-crime' map of working-class areas, penalizing communities for trouble that hasn't happened yet.

Cross-border health services (CAWT) want to merge patient data for people living in Donegal who access cancer treatment in Derry. It saves lives, but with the UK ditching GDPR standards post-Brexit, your medical history is suddenly sitting on a server outside EU protection. Do you sign the consent form to get the chemo?

Big Tech is finally building Irish language models, but they're training them on the 'Caighdeán Oifigiúil' (Official Standard) and ignoring the rich dialects of Connemara, Kerry, and Donegal. If the AI corrects a native speaker's grammar because it doesn't recognize the dialect, are we preserving the language or sterilizing it for corporate use?

A startup wants to use AI to generate new 'Irish folklore' stories for tourists, perfect English with a cupla focal thrown in. It'll sell well in gift shops in Killarney, but it crowds out actual Gaeltacht artists and storytellers who can't compete with the speed of generation. Is it cultural promotion or cultural strip-mining?

The government wants to use automated translation for official documents to meet EU parity requirements because they can't find enough human translators. The AI makes subtle legal errors that could disadvantage Irish speakers in court. Do we accept 'good enough' Irish from a machine, or insist on rights that the state technically can't deliver?

Smart speakers in Gaeltacht homes still don't understand Irish commands. A local initiative wants to record children in Gaelscoileanna to build a dataset to train Alexa. It empowers the kids to use their language, but it involves handing over thousands of hours of children's voices to Amazon. Is the convenience worth the privacy trade-off?

Predictive text on smartphones is actively eroding Irish grammar, auto-correcting the tuiseal ginideach (genitive case) out of existence because users get tired of fighting the spellcheck. Do we demand Apple and Google fix their algorithms, or accept that the language will morph to fit the QWERTY keyboard?

A planning authority AI approves housing in the Gaeltacht based on economic metrics, ignoring linguistic impact assessments. It approves a generic housing estate that will likely be filled by English speakers, diluting the language area further. The computer says 'growth', the community says 'death'. Who wins?

Synthetic voice technology is being used to resurrect the voices of long-dead Blasket Islanders to read audiobooks. It's hauntingly beautiful, but did Peig Sayers consent to reading the weather forecast on an app? At what point does digital preservation become digital puppetry?

Irish language activists are building a 'sovereign' dataset, refusing to license it to OpenAI or Google. It protects the culture from capitalization, but it means Irish will lag behind in functionality on every major platform. Do we choose digital isolation or corporate assimilation?

Dublin is the data center capital of Europe. These server farms are drinking water while the city faces drought restrictions, and they use as much electricity as a small city. We're told they bring 'tech prestige', but they employ nobody and threaten the grid. Do we pull the plug on a new Amazon center to keep the lights on in Phibsboro?

Tech workers in the 'Silicon Docks' get housing stipends that inflate rents for everyone else. An app automates bidding on rentals, ensuring a Google engineer always beats the local nurse. It's the free market on steroids. Do we regulate the algorithms that determine who gets a roof over their head?

Airbnb's algorithm pushes hosts to turn long-term rentals into short-term lets for tourists in West Cork. Entire villages are empty in winter and unaffordable in summer. The platform says it's 'empowering locals', but the local school is closing due to lack of families. Do we ban the app to save the village?

A 'Co-living' startup proposes 10sqm pods in Dublin city center, marketed as 'tech-enabled flexible living' for €1200 a month. The planning AI approves it as 'efficient density'. It's basically a tenement with high-speed WiFi. Do we accept this lowering of living standards just to house the tech workforce?

Vulture funds use sophisticated predictive models to buy up housing estates in commuter towns before a single brick is laid, purely for the rental yield. First-time buyers can't compete with an algorithm that buys 500 homes in a millisecond. Is it ethical to let code dictate home ownership?

The Council wants to use satellite imagery and utility data to identify vacant homes during the housing crisis to levy taxes. It's invasive surveillance of private property, but when there are 10,000 homeless people, does the right to privacy trump the moral crime of hoarding empty houses?

PropTech software used by major landlords is accused of implicit price-fixing, suggesting rent hikes across the board based on 'market optimization'. Rents in Cork go up in unison. It's not a cartel meeting in a smoke-filled room, it's an algorithm. How do you prosecute a piece of code for rack-renting?

A data center offers to heat a social housing complex with its waste heat. It sounds like a win-win, but it locks the community into dependency on a tech giant's infrastructure. If the data center moves out because corporate tax rates change, does the heating go off?

The National Broadband Plan is years behind. A private satellite company offers instant connectivity to rural Kerry but demands total data mining rights in exchange for the subsidized hardware. It's the only way to run a business in the mountains, but it sells out the community's privacy. Is broadband a right or a data transaction?

Bord na Móna is rewetting the bogs, and carbon credit companies are using drones to monitor the sequestration. They want to restrict turf cutting rights for locals based on satellite heat maps. It's saving the planet, but it feels like another absentee landlord telling the locals what they can't do with their own plot.

John Deere tractors are now so software-locked that a farmer in Mayo can't fix his own engine without a licensed technician from Dublin. The 'Right to Repair' movement is fighting it, but the manufacturers threaten to void warranties. Do we support the local mechanic hacking the software, or the IP rights of the corporation?

Telehealth kiosks are being rolled out in rural post offices to replace closing GP surgeries. It's 'efficient', but try telling an 80-year-old woman to discuss her ailments with a screen in the back of a shop where the neighbours might hear. Is this healthcare, or just managed decline of rural services?

Autonomous forestry machinery is being tested in Leitrim to plant Sitka spruce plantations. The machines don't stop for coffee and don't spend money in the local shop. It's 'green economy' investment, but it provides zero local employment while covering the county in darkness. Is it progress if it empties the parish?

Tourist authorities want to track rental cars via GPS to manage traffic on the Wild Atlantic Way, penalizing tourists who go off-road or block local lanes. It would solve the traffic chaos, but it turns the West into a geofenced theme park. Do we treat visitors like cattle to preserve our own sanity?

A massive wind farm is proposed off the coast using AI to minimize bird strikes, but the visual impact algorithm says it's 'negligible'. The locals say it ruins the horizon. The energy is needed for the Dublin data centers, not the local grid. Are rural communities just batteries for the capital's tech boom?

Smart meters are being forced on rural homes with poor 4G signals. The estimated billing algorithms are overcharging elderly people who can't access the app to correct the readings. The energy company says 'trust the system', but the system thinks a cottage in Roscommon uses as much power as a semi-d in Foxrock.

The Mother and Baby Homes records are being digitized. A database could help survivors find family, but the Church and State cite GDPR to seal the records for another 30 years. Is privacy being weaponized to protect the institutions rather than the victims? Do we hack the archives to get the truth?

AI facial recognition is being run on hours of archival footage from the Troubles. It identifies people who were throwing stones in 1982 who are now respectable politicians or community leaders. Does the Good Friday Agreement cover digital excavation of the past, or are we opening old wounds for clicks?

The 'Boston College Tapes' debacle showed the danger of oral history. Now, researchers want to use AI to anonymize voice recordings of ex-paramilitaries to preserve the history without risking prosecution. Can you truly anonymize a voice that tells a story only three people know? Is the risk to the contributor worth the historical record?

DNA testing sites like Ancestry are hugely popular in the diaspora. They are inadvertently exposing non-paternity events and secret adoptions from Ireland's darker past, shattering families. Do we have a right to genetic truth even if it destroys the peace of an 80-year-old woman who kept a secret all her life?

A tech company wants to create a VR experience of the 1916 Rising. It's immersive education, but they want to gamify it—giving points for 'kills'. Turning our foundational national trauma into a Call of Duty clone feels sacrilegious, but the kids won't read the history books. Do we debase the history to keep it alive?

Digital forensics are being used to search for the 'Disappeared' in bogland. The tech is expensive and funds are limited. The algorithm gives probabilities: 80% chance here, 20% there. Who decides which family gets the dig and which family keeps waiting? The algorithm decides who gets closure.

The state wants to digitize the Land Commission records. It would reveal exactly who took whose land during the revolution and the famine. In rural Ireland, where grudges last 100 years, making this data searchable on a map could reignite feuds that have been dormant for generations. Some history is safer in a dusty basement.

Deepfake technology is used to create a 'Message from the Future' delivered by Michael Collins. It's used in a political campaign to advocate for a United Ireland. It's technically impressive, but putting words in the mouth of a dead patriot to influence a modern vote crosses a line. Is the Big Fellow public property?
